content: Really hard in reverse mode I hope this clash gets removed.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Despite the negative note from other users,  I find that this challenge is funny. Some tests with "base 2" and binary numbers help me to find that the first line is the base and the 2nd line are numbers (and again with "base 16" and hex digits). When this point is solved, it is not very difficult to find that this is a modulus. 
Test 11 is very useful to know that hex digits are uppercase in output. Thanks for this test.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: There is no clue about the intention of the problem. Why do you think it is obvious to think about the solution?
I did not understand the problem. Is module (c) given in base (b)? If not IMO it needs to be consistent with num (a) which is given in base (b).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think the difficulty of this reversing mode CoC problem is just right.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Took me only 4 minutes for some reason.
I do like that you first need to figure out radix stuff and then modulo. This type of step by step investigation compensates for the fact that it's "guess the formula reverse."

I've changed this submission according to the only feedback given by anyone. In my opinion, taking out some of the tests makes it less interesting, but I did it.
Thank you to anyone who offers any feedback.

Wrong stub - if those variables are on single line , you should write read of them on single line f.e.: `read row:int col:int` Your STUB simply won't run on most languages

You should write at least minimalist statement for reverse mode. Don't worry it won't be shown during clash

There is no way I'd come with the solution, maybe put "BASE" in separate line, so that I can understand, that the number has different meaning than other 2? Now it simply looks like I have to consider all numbers to be in base 16

Reverse mode should be clear from first 4 tests
The explanation is in a comment at the end of the solution code.

Thanks a lot for the feedback. I've updated the stub form and the variable names. I have seen reverse mode with a standard text that I wasn't able to find. It looks like the other current submissions just wrote "<reverse>" for everything. But I added a short text now.
I am not sure I agree completely on being clear from the first 4 tests. I think it's definitely clear from the last. Maybe there are too many. I will revise further.
Thanks man!
boi, why are you so salty, it has 28 days left to validate and already some feedback.

They're both such common elements here that I'm surprised I haven't seen this combination before.
I originally had more odd radices, so most of us wouldn't know for sure until trying some code, but maybe that's not needed.

Given the 5th test:

2
10001 1010  ->  110

I believe anyone who understands what base 2 is will guess that (b), (c) and the expected output are all given in base (a), even before they understand what B and C represent.
All of the tests and validators follow this pattern. If they didn't, the posted solution would not work.
The explanation is in the statement and at the end of the solution code.

Well, we'll see. It's not my choice now. But if this is unfathomably hard, you will truly hate hundreds of the clashes on this site, far more complex than this. I've been doing them for a year or so, and I've noticed the quality dropping as incredibly complex clashes get approved, even with some approvers commenting that it took them 20 minutes to solve, etc.
Radices and moduli are both very common in these puzzles, so I suppose, if you've done a few hundred, you'll tend to notice them. In this case, that's all the puzzle is - nothing more - which I believe makes it pretty simple compared to the majority, but obviously not everyone sees it the same way I do.
By the way, I think you noticed that it is submitted ONLY as reverse mode, right?
Thats why I rejected. It is not intuitive at all to guess the solution.
How do we guess we need to use c as modulo? It is not obvious at least to me.

OK, then maybe it is not clear enough.
My thought was that, after seeing that the first number is always 2, 8, 10 or 16, the player would go back and look at the other numbers again, considering them in that base, and notice the modulo element maybe in base 10:
10
47 2 -> 1
or
10
45 6 -> 3

The idea being that, after figuring out what the radix is, there's less to try to calculate.
I will look over the tests, maybe I can make one that's more obvious, like:
10
57  10  -> 7
And maybe base 8 isn't needed at all.
It's good as it is.
